questions.text: A 30-year-old computer scientist receives negative feedback on a recent project from his senior associate. He is told sternly that he must improve his performance on the next project. Later that day, he yells at his intern, a college student, for not showing enough initiative, though he had voiced only satisfaction with his performance up until this point. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Projection (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes their thoughts, emotions, or behavior to another person. An example of projection would be if the computer scientist had a poor performance because he was lazy and then he accused his intern of laziness. In this scenario, the computer scientist redirects his anger from its real target (his senior associate) to a neutral third party (the intern), which is best described by a different term.

B) CORRECT:

Displacement (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual redirects negative emotions from its real target to a neutral third party. The neutral third party is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. The computer scientist is displacing his anger at his senior associate to his intern.

C) INCORRECT:

Countertransference is a term used in psychoanalysis to refer to the effect that the patient has on the psychotherapist. Countertransference is not a defense mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Controlling (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual attempts to excessively manage or regulate the environment (i.e., objects or people) to minimize or avoid anxiety. Controlling individuals may become angry if their instructions are not carefully followed. However, this computer scientist's anger at his intern is not the result of the intern's failure to follow instructions but rather a result of the computer scientist being berated earlier by a senior associate.

E) INCORRECT:

Reaction formation is a neurotic defense reaction in which an individual replaces an undesired idea or feeling by acting in a diametrically opposite fashion. For example, a nymphomaniac who becomes a nun, or a man who insults a woman because he is in love with her.

F) INCORRECT:

Externalization (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her internal characteristics to the outside world but does not realize that he/she is actually the one with those characteristics. For example, a scientist who is collaborating with a statistician claims that they haven't been productive because the statistician is extremely lazy when it is actually the scientist who is lazy.

G) INCORRECT:

A person who is acting out may yell to express negative feelings or thoughts that he/she cannot express calmly and coherently. However, the deliberate redirection of emotions to a subordinate employee indicates a different defense mechanism.

H) INCORRECT:

Transference refers to the unconscious redirection of feelings (positive or negative) from a past experience (often from childhood) with one object to a current experience with another object that has a perceived or real similarity to the first object. For example, the computer scientist decides to yell at an intern who unconsciously reminds him of a former classmate who used to bully him in school. Within the context of psychoanalysis, the term transference refers to the projection of unconscious feelings by the patient onto the therapist.

I) INCORRECT:

Distortion (psychiatry) is a defense mechanism in which the individual reshapes his/her perception of an upsetting reality to be more acceptable. For example, the computer scientist had a poor performance and attributes his poor performance to a conspiracy that has been started by his senior associate to prevent him from getting tenure.
questions.hint: Another example of this defense mechanism would be a student yelling at his dog after being told by his teacher that he has detention.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a suburban town and has never knowingly been in contact with anyone who is not heterosexual. Two days ago, he joined a local group seeking to criminalize homosexual activity. Together with other members, he verbally and physically assaulted a same-sex couple on their way home from dinner. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A person who is acting out uses confrontational actions to express feelings or thoughts that he/she cannot express verbally: e.g., a gay man in a heterosexual marriage who constantly fights with his wife.

B) INCORRECT:

Denial (psychiatry) is an immature ego defense mechanism that involves refusing to accept the truth of a fact or situation that is difficult to deal with by acting as if the reality of that fact or situation does not exist: e.g., an individual with a substance use disorder who refuses to acknowledge his or her addiction and argues that he or she has full control of the substance use. This man is acting in a manner that is diametrically opposed to his feelings, which is more characteristic of a different defense mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Sexualization (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism that refers to an inappropriate imposition of sexual significance on a person: e.g., an office worker who will not stop talking about his female coworker's "assets" because she is outperforming him in the workplace.

D) INCORRECT:

Sublimation (psychiatry) refers to the transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse or a detrimental emotion into goal-directed, socially acceptable actions: e.g., an individual who channels his or her aggressive impulses at work into playing rugby, a sport in which aggression is more socially acceptable.

E) CORRECT:

Reaction formation is a neurotic ego defense mechanism in which an undesired idea or feeling is replaced by acting in a diametrically opposed manner. This patient has joined a group that supports the criminalization of homosexuality and assaulted a same-sex couple instead of accepting the possibility that he might be gay or bisexual.

F) INCORRECT:

Intellectualization is the use of abstract, rational, or logical reasoning to avoid acknowledging a conflict and the stress and emotions associated with it: e.g., excessively investigating the pathophysiology of a terminal illness instead of reacting to feelings of anxiety, anger, or insecurity.

G) INCORRECT:

Projection (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her thoughts, emotions, or behavior to the thoughts, emotions, or behavior of another individual: e.g., a philandering husband who thinks that his partner is also cheating on him.
questions.hint: Another example of this defense mechanism would be a man who is angry at a coworker but acts particularly friendly towards him/her.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is on a week-long cruise vacation with his family to celebrate his mother's 80th birthday. He has a very important presentation at work to give in one month, which will in part determine whether he receives a promotion. He decides to focus on enjoying the vacation and not to worry about the presentation until the cruise is over. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Isolation of affect is a neurotic ego defense and like most ego defenses, it typically operates at a subconscious level. An individual with isolation of affect would not have any emotional response to a distressing thought (e.g., a terminally ill patient who informs his family of his diagnosis with no display of emotions).

B) INCORRECT:

Repression (psychiatry) involves the prevention of unpleasant or distressing thoughts. Repression is a neurotic defense mechanism, and like most ego defenses, it occurs involuntarily; for example, a person who was abused and does not remember being mistreated.

C) INCORRECT:

Introjection is an immature ego defense and like most ego defenses, it typically operates at a subconscious level. An individual exhibiting introjection would subconsciously imitate the behavior, both good and bad, of an older person or an authority figure; for example, an employee who inadvertently becomes lazy because his/her manager is also lazy.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition (psychiatry) refers to the subconscious restriction of a behavioral or verbal response even though the stimulus for the response is present. This patient's behavior is the result of a decision that was made after deliberation.

E) INCORRECT:

Dissociation (psychiatry) refers to the temporary disruption of one's sense of self or personal identity in order to avoid dealing with emotions that may possibly be painful; for example, a person who was mugged recalls the incident as an out-of-body experience. Dissociation is a neurotic defense mechanism, and like most ego defenses, it typically operates at a subconscious level.

F) INCORRECT:

Displacement (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism and like most ego defenses, it typically operates at a subconscious level. An individual exhibiting displacement (psychiatry) redirects emotions from its intended target to a neutral third party; e.g., a manager who has been yelled at by the CEO takes it out on his employees.

G) INCORRECT:

Blocking (psychiatry) may occur when the individual is under a lot of stress. However, blocking is an immature defense mechanism, which involves a transient, involuntary interruption of a thought process; for example, a person who suddenly forgets what they have to do next.

H) INCORRECT:

Regression (psychiatry) is an immature ego defense and like most ego defenses, it typically operates at a subconscious level. An individual exhibiting regression reverts back to an earlier stage of development; e.g., an adult who has temper tantrums instead of communicating effectively when he/she has workplace problems.

I) INCORRECT:

Denial (psychiatry) involves a subconscious refusal to accept unpleasant aspects of a reality; e.g., an employee who shows up for work even after having been fired.

J) CORRECT:

Suppression (psychiatry) is the conscious and intentional avoidance of unwanted feelings and thoughts (see “Overview of mature defenses” table). Suppression is a temporary reaction and usually ends with exposure to a stimulus that reminds the individual of the unwanted thought. By contrast, repression is a neurotic defense mechanism involving the unconscious avoidance of unwanted feelings and thoughts.
questions.hint: This individual is exhibiting a mature ego defense mechanism, which is the result of conscious effort (unlike other defense mechanisms that operate at a subconscious level). Another example would be a married woman who actively decides to ignore feelings of attraction towards her husband's best friend.

questions.text: A 35-year-old engineer is told by his boss that his team will need to work extra evening hours in the coming week in order to meet a project deadline. This frustrates the engineer, who already feels he is working too many hours. Instead of discussing the topic directly with his boss, the engineer calls in sick and leaves his work for his boss to finish. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is this individual demonstrating?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticipation (psychiatry) is a mature defense mechanism that makes realistic provisions for difficult situations in the future, e.g., going over course notes in preparation for a lecture the next morning. Calling in sick to avoid work out of frustration is an immature rather than mature defense mechanism. An anticipatory reaction in this vignette's individual would be to begin looking for a new job or schedule a meeting with his boss to discuss the long working hours and adequate compensation.

B) INCORRECT:

Displacement (psychiatry) refers to the redirection of impulses and emotions from a target that is perceived as threatening or unacceptable to another that is perceived as more acceptable or less threatening; e.g., a manager may take out his frustration at the company CEO on subordinates; a child might take out his anger at his parents on his younger brother.

C) INCORRECT:

Acting out is the expression of repressed or unconscious emotions in an impulsive and unrestrained manner; e.g., knocking over one's desk after getting fired.

D) INCORRECT:

Distortion (psychiatry) is a defense mechanism in which individuals reshape their perception of an upsetting reality to be more acceptable. Distortion is usually associated with psychotic disorders.

E) CORRECT:

Passive aggression is an immature defense mechanism in which individuals express negative feelings toward someone in a nonconfrontational way. Rather than confront his boss about feeling overworked and undervalued, he feigns illness and thereby forces his boss to take over his workload (see “Overview of immature defenses” table).

F) INCORRECT:

Individuals with somatization experience and/or express psychological distress as somatic symptoms (e.g., pain). The context suggests that this individual is deliberately feigning illness because of frustration with his job.

G) INCORRECT:

Blocking (psychiatry) refers to the transient interruption of the thought process, e.g., when a person suddenly forgets the reason for calling a friend.

H) INCORRECT:

Individuals with hypochondriasis have a persistent obsession with their health and/or the possibility of developing a disease. The context suggests that this individual is deliberately feigning illness because of frustration with his job.
questions.hint: Another example of this defense mechanism would be someone leaving a magazine article about annoying eating habits (loud chewing, chewing with mouth open, etc.) on a coworker's desk in reaction to feeling annoyed with the coworker's eating habits during lunch breaks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is physically and verbally abusive toward his wife and two children. When he was a child, he and his mother were similarly abused by his father. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is this man demonstrating?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fantasy is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual believes in fantastical or magical ideas in order to cope with a difficult or painful reality: e.g., a child believing that a superhero will rescue them from a difficult household or believing in the power of amulets.

B) INCORRECT:

In primitive idealization, an individual does not change their mind once they have classified something as “good.” Any perceived deviation from this idealized notion is immediately rationalized by the individual as the outcome of a personal failure or shortcoming: e.g., a woman who is in an abusive marriage attributes her partner's behavior to her failure to be a good wife.

C) CORRECT:

Identification (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual adapts their behavior, whether good or bad, to the behavior of another person. Identification may occur with a survivor of aggression (e.g., a mother who was abused), an aggressor, a love interest, or a deceased individual (e.g., a sibling or friend who passed away). The classic example of identification with an aggressor is an abused child who later becomes an abusive parent. By identifying with the abusive behavior and internalizing it, they can fend off and mask the fear they experienced and can transform themselves from a frightened individual into the one who induces fear.

D) INCORRECT:

Distortion (psychiatry) is a defense mechanism in which the individual reshapes their perception of an upsetting reality to be more acceptable. Distortion is usually associated with psychotic disorders.

E) INCORRECT:

Regression (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual reverts back to an earlier stage of development: e.g., an adult who has temper tantrums instead of communicating effectively when they have problems in the workplace.

F) INCORRECT:

Projection (psychiatry) is a defense mechanism in which the individual attributes their undesired thoughts or emotions to another individual(s): e.g., a husband who has an affair believes that his wife is also cheating.

G) INCORRECT:

Splitting (psychiatry) is a defense mechanism in which the individual classifies all things as entirely good or entirely bad and may rapidly shift their opinion between these two extreme opinions: e.g., a student who believes that their teacher is “the best teacher in the world” when they receive praise but rapidly changes their mind and believes the teacher is “evil” when they receive a bad grade.

H) INCORRECT:

Reaction formation is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual responds to an undesired idea or feeling by acting in a diametrically opposite fashion: e.g., a man who insults a woman because he is in love with her.
questions.hint: Another example of this defense mechanism would be a young girl, who, without realizing it, begins to dress more and more like her revered older cousin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He reports that he recently found out that his wife had an affair with her personal trainer and that she now left him for her new partner. The patient is alone with their two children now. To be able to care for them, he had to reduce his working hours and give up playing tennis twice a week. When asked about his feeling towards his wife and the situation, he reports that he has read several books about human emotion recently. He says, “Falling in love has neurological effects similar to those of amphetamines. I suppose, my wife was just seeking stimulation.” Which of the following defense mechanisms best describes this patient's reaction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rationalization (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism in which individuals come up with excuses or feasible explanations to justify ideas, actions, or emotions, often in order to avoid self-blame. An example of rationalization in this case would be if the patient gave alternative reasons to justify his wife's behavior (e.g., that the personal trainer forced her into a relationship). What we see instead is the patient using logical reasoning to avoid negative emotions, which is better described by a different defense mechanism.

B) CORRECT:

Intellectualization is a neurotic defense mechanism in which individuals use abstract, rational, and/or logical reasoning to avoid affective expression and distance themselves from stress. By explaining his wife's behavior in technical, neurological terms, this patient transposes his experience from an emotional to an intellectual level and thus defers confrontation with the reality of his situation.

C) INCORRECT:

If the defense mechanism displayed here was isolation of affect, this patient would talk about the strong emotions because of the breakup without actually showing any emotions. While this man does speak very rationally about emotions, it is not his emotions he is speaking about but his wife's.

D) INCORRECT:

If the defense mechanism displayed here was splitting (psychiatry), the father would have an all-good or all-bad view of his wife and perceive her, for example, as the one, who was solely to blame for the failure of their marriage.

E) INCORRECT:

If the defense mechanism displayed here was denial (psychiatry), he would refuse to accept the breakup rather than try to find explanations for it to avoid having to face the fact and deal with the pain of accepting it.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's statement could also be perceived as sarcastic, its context (prompted by his study of human emotion) suggests that he is not trying to be humorous in line with the humor (psychiatry) defense mechanism, but rather actually trying to explain his wife's behavior, which is better explained by another defense mechanism.

G) INCORRECT:

In sublimation (psychiatry), the focus of unacceptable impulses is shifted towards goal-directed activities; typically moving towards a personally and socially acceptable direction. A conceivable example of sublimation in this case would be if the father channeled his aggression towards his wife into art or sports rather than trying to explain her behavior.

H) INCORRECT:

If the defense mechanism displayed here was suppression (psychiatry), he would try to avoid thinking about the breakup rather than seek explanations for it.

I) INCORRECT:

If the defense mechanism displayed here was externalization (psychiatry), he would have projected his own anger, frustration, or sadness onto someone else and, for example, perceived his wife as angry or aggressive and himself as even-tempered.
questions.hint: This patient's reaction can be classified as a neurotic defense mechanism (level III). It is used to avoid affective expression.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the therapist for weekly psychotherapy. She was diagnosed with major depressive disorder and anxiety after her divorce 1 year ago. During last week's appointment, she spoke about her ex-husband's timidity and lack of advancement at work; despite her urging, he never asked for a raise. Today, when the therapist asks how she is doing, she replies, “If there's something you want to know, have the courage to ask me! I have no respect for a man who won't speak his mind!” The patient's behavior can be best described as an instance of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Transference is a phenomenon in which a patient projects feelings (positive and/or negative) about important persons onto the clinician. This woman projects her frustrations about her ex-husband's timidity onto the therapist. Transference is not a type of defense mechanism.

Countertransference is a similar phenomenon in which clinicians project feelings about important persons onto patients (e.g., by viewing patients as their children).

B) INCORRECT:

Displacement (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual redirects impulses and emotions from a target that is perceived as threatening or unacceptable to another that is perceived as less threatening or more acceptable. Though this woman directs her frustrations about her ex-husband's timidity to the therapist, she has confronted her ex-husband in the past and is less likely to perceive him as a threatening or unacceptable target.

C) INCORRECT:

Projection (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual projects an unacceptable internal impulse onto an external source. If this woman were frustrated at her therapist and accused the therapist of being frustrated at her, she would exhibit this defense mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Passive aggression is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual demonstrates negative feelings in an indirect, nonconfrontational manner. If this woman did not confront her ex-husband about his timidity and instead expressed her discontent through passive behaviors such as deliberate failure to contribute to shared responsibilities, she would exhibit this defense mechanism.

E) INCORRECT:

Reaction formation is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual replaces an unacceptable internal impulse with its opposite. If this woman were frustrated with her therapist but instead treated her with exaggerated kindness, she would exhibit this defense mechanism.

F) INCORRECT:

Externalization (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which an individual projects internal characteristics (e.g., moods, attitudes) onto the external world. If this woman projected her frustrations about her husband's timidity onto the therapist and believed that the therapist was frustrated with her husband, she would exhibit this defense mechanism.
questions.hint: This woman described her ex-husband as being timid last week and now reacts to a conversational formality as if the therapist were behaving timidly.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with hypertension and dyslipidemia comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He says he feels well. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 103 kg (227 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His BMI last year was 27 kg/m2. When asked about his diet, he says, “Being overweight runs in my family. Rather than fight it, I just try to enjoy myself and eat what I want.” Which of the following defense mechanisms best describes the patient's response to the physician?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Denial (psychiatry) is a pathological defense mechanism in which the individual consciously avoids anxiety-provoking thoughts by refusing to accept reality. It is a common early response to bad news (e.g., refusing to acknowledge a cancer diagnosis). Denial is also sometimes seen in patients with substance use disorders, who often deny having a problem.

B) CORRECT:

Rationalization is a neurotic defense mechanism that involves offering excuses or rational explanations in an attempt to justify behaviors, attitudes, or beliefs to avoid self-blame. The way in which this patient uses his family history of obesity as a rationale for overeating and his own weight is, therefore, an example of rationalization.

C) INCORRECT:

In primitive idealization, an individual does not reflect critically on something or someone he/she has classified as “good.” Any perceived deviation from the idealized notion he/she has of someone or something is immediately rationalized as being a result of a personal failure or shortcoming (e.g., a woman who is in an abusive marriage but attributes her partner's behavior to her failure to be a good wife).

D) INCORRECT:

Fantasy (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual withdraws into fantasy to avoid internal and external sources of conflict (e.g., a homeless man who pretends to be rich and always daydreams about running his own corporation).

E) INCORRECT:

Distortion (psychiatry) is a pathological defense mechanism in which the individual reshapes his/her perception of an external reality (e.g., an upsetting event) to suit his/her inner needs. An example of distortion (psychiatry) might be someone who maintains they were abandoned by their family when they actually ran away from home.

F) INCORRECT:

Intellectualization is a neurotic defense mechanism that refers to the excessive reliance on facts and logic to avoid acknowledging or confronting one's emotions (e.g., excessively investigating the pathophysiology of a terminal illness instead of reacting to the anxiety brought on by the diagnosis).
questions.hint: The patient is using his own logic to avoid taking responsibility for his diet and weight.

Transference refers to the unconscious redirection of feelings (positive or negative) from a past experience (often from childhood) with one object to a current experience with another object that has a perceived or real similarity to the first object. For example, the senior resident decides to yell at an intern who unconsciously reminds him of a former classmate who used to bully him in school. Within the context of psychoanalysis, the term transference refers to the projection of unconscious feelings by the patient onto the therapist.

B) INCORRECT:

Countertransference is a term used in psychoanalysis to refer to the effect that the patient has on the psychotherapist. Countertransference is not a defense mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Externalization is a neurotic defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her internal characteristics to the outside world but does not realize that he/she is actually the one with those characteristics. For example, a scientist who is collaborating with a statistician claims that they haven't been productive because the statistician is extremely lazy when it is actually the scientist who is lazy.

D) CORRECT:

Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism in which an individual redirects negative emotions from its real target to a neutral third party. The neutral third party is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. The senior resident is displacing his anger at his attending to his medical student.

E) INCORRECT:

Projection is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual attributes his/her thoughts, emotions, or behavior to the thoughts, emotions, or behavior of another individual(s). For example, the senior resident had a poor performance because he was lazy; he attributes the student's poor performance to laziness as well when the student's poor performance could actually have been the result of ill health.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is in her last few months at community college. She has a very important essay due in 2 weeks that will play a big part in determining her final grades. She decides to focus on writing this essay and not to worry about her grades until it is completed. Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains her behavior?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repression (psychiatry) involves the unconscious removal of unpleasant or distressing thoughts from conscious awareness. Repression is a neurotic defense mechanism, and like most ego defenses, it occurs involuntarily; for example, a person who was abused and does not remember being mistreated.

B) CORRECT:

Suppression (psychiatry), a mature defense mechanism, refers to intentionally or consciously choosing not to think about a feeling or thought that provokes anxiety. Other mature defense mechanisms include: altruism (psychiatry), humor (psychiatry), sublimation (psychiatry), and anticipation (psychiatry).

C) INCORRECT:

Blocking (psychiatry) may occur when the individual is under a lot of stress, similar to this woman. However, blocking is an immature defense mechanism, and it involves the transient, involuntary interruption of the thought process. For example, a person who suddenly forgets what he/she has to do next.

D) INCORRECT:

Dissociation (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism that refers to a temporary, subconscious disruption of one's sense of self or personal identity in order to avoid dealing with emotions that may possibly be painful. For example, a person who was mugged recalls the incident as an out-of-body experience.

E) INCORRECT:

Displacement (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism and, like most ego defenses, it typically operates at a subconscious level. An individual exhibiting displacement (psychiatry) redirects emotions from its intended target to a neutral third party; e.g., a manager who has been yelled at by the CEO takes it out on his employees.

F) INCORRECT:

Denial (psychiatry) involves a subconscious refusal to accept unpleasant aspects of a reality that may provoke anxiety (similar to the woman above). However, denial is a narcissistic defense mechanism and is a common initial response to bad news (e.g., an employee who shows up for work even after having been fired).
questions.hint: This individual is exhibiting a mature ego defense mechanism, which is the result of conscious effort (unlike other defense mechanisms that operate at a subconscious level). Another example would be a man in a relationship who is about to go abroad for a year without his partner actively choosing to ignore the feeling of loneliness that is starting to build up.

questions.text: A 42-year-old biochemist receives negative feedback from a senior associate on a recent project. He is placed on probation within the company and told that he must improve his performance on the next project to remain with the company. He is distraught and leaves his office early. When he gives an account of the episode to his wife, she says, “I'll always be proud of you no matter what because I know that you always try your best.” Later that night, he tearfully accuses her of believing that he is a failure. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Denial (psychiatry) involves a subconscious refusal to accept unpleasant aspects of a reality. For example, the biochemist would demonstrate denial if he showed up for work even after having been fired.

B) CORRECT:

Projection (psychiatry) is a pathological defense mechanism in which individuals attribute their thoughts, emotions, or behavior to another individual (or other individuals). The biochemist, who thinks he is a failure, is accusing his wife of not believing in him, although she has told him the exact opposite. He thereby extends his undesired feelings about himself to another person (see “Overview of pathological defenses” table).

C) INCORRECT:

Transference refers to the unconscious redirection of feelings (positive or negative) from a past experience (often from childhood) with one object to a current experience with another object that has a perceived or real similarity to the first object. Within the context of psychoanalysis, the term transference refers to the projection of unconscious feelings by the patient onto the therapist.

D) INCORRECT:

Close! This patient's defense mechanism is similar to displacement (psychiatry), so you're on the right track. Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism in which the affected individual redirects negative emotions about one person to a neutral third party (i.e., person or object), which is often a subordinate or less threatening entity. An example of displacement would be if the biochemist yelled at an intern for not showing enough initiative after having received negative feedback himself. In this case, the biochemist attributes emotions he has about himself to another person (his wife), which is better described by a different defense mechanism.

E) INCORRECT:

Passive aggression refers to the expression of negative feelings towards someone in a non-confrontational way. For example, a biochemist who is told to work overtime for a project is frustrated, because he feels like he is already working too many hours. Instead of discussing this directly with his boss, he calls in sick and leaves his work for his boss to finish.

F) INCORRECT:

Externalization (psychiatry) is a neurotic defense mechanism in which the individual attributes their internal characteristics to the outside world but does not realize that they are actually the one with those characteristics. For example, a biochemist who is collaborating with a statistician claims that they haven't been productive because the statistician is extremely lazy when it is actually the scientist who is lazy.
questions.hint: Another example of this defense mechanism: a man who is attracted to a woman accuses her of subtly flirting with him when she isn't.

When she is with her friends in public, she never misses an opportunity to make derogatory comments about same-sex couples she sees. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is she demonstrating?
